qas.question: What was Charles VII chamberlain ordered to do?
What did the knight leave at the summit of Rocciamelone?

answers.text: a bronze triptych of three crosses

qas.question: When did Antioine de Ville climb Mont Aiguille?
When did four Chamonix men almost reach the summit of Mont Blanc?

context: Charles VII of <a0_0>France<a0_0/> ordered his chamberlain to <a1_0>climb Mont Aiguille<a1_0/> in 1356. The knight reached the summit of Rocciamelone where he left <a2_0>a bronze triptych of three crosses<a2_0/>, a feat which he conducted with the use of ladders to traverse the ice. In <a3_0>1492<a3_0/> Antoine de Ville climbed Mont Aiguille, without reaching the summit, an experience he described as "horrifying and terrifying." Leonardo da Vinci was fascinated by variations of light in the higher altitudes, and climbed a mountain—scholars are uncertain which one; some believe it may have been Monte Rosa. From his description of a "blue like that of a gentian" sky it is thought that he reached a significantly high altitude. In the <a4_0>18th century<a4_0/> four Chamonix man almost made the summit of Mont Blanc but were overcome by altitude sickness and snowblindness.
